The author also argues that an "anarchy of production" is established with the institution of private property, in which all producers' relations are voluntary and mutually beneficial.

The author argues that all socialist property should be forfeited and returned to the original owners or their heirs, as it was obtained through expropriation. The original property titles should be recognized and current users' claims should be overridden by original private owners or their heirs unless the user can prove that the original title was acquired by coercion or fraud. In case the socialist property is not reclaimed, ownership should be transferred to those who use it, such as the farmland to farmers, factories to workers, etc. The property shares acquired in this way should be freely tradeable and a stock market established to allow for transfer from less productive hands to more productive ones. The author references the writings of Murray N. Rothbard and John Locke to support these ideas.

Under Syndicalism, the means of production are not allowed to have the property arrangements of Capitalism. Instead, individual citizens are assigned shares in the means of production, which cannot be disposed of. However, this approach creates two problems: first, what should be done in the case of newly erected structures built on land that is owned by someone else; and second, producers in capital-intensive industries will have a relative advantage over those in labor-intensive industries, leading to unequal distribution of wealth. The author argues that the latter issue can be justified by the homesteading principle, where private property is established through acts of homesteading (mixing one's labor with nature-given resources before anyone else has done so), and that this principle can be applied to the syndicalist privatization approach as well. The workers in Syndicalism are not considered "owners" in the normal sense of the word because they cannot dispose of their shares in the means of production in any way they consider most advantageous. This creates difficulties if changes occur in methods of production, supply and demand, technique or population. In this case, either workers would keep their shares in the means of production they occupied at the time of syndicalization and enter new industries as simple workers earning wages, or they would lose their share on leaving an industry and receive a share per head equal to that of workers already working in the new industry. Either way, this would quickly violate the principle of Syndicalism and make every change in production virtually impossible, blocking economic progress.

This section discusses the economic theory of bargaining and the concept of property. The author cites several works by Murray N. Rothbard, Robert Nozick, Helmut Schoeck, Erik von Kuehnelt-Leddihn, and John Locke to support their argument. The author endorses Locke's idea of homesteading and criticizes the "proviso" in his theory of original appropriation. The author also critiques modern variants of the Lockean proviso and land-egalitarianism. The author presents a syndicalist proposal for privatization that is more efficient than an alternative plan that would give equal shares to the entire population. The author suggests adopting a private property constitution that lays out clear principles for private ownership and the prosecution of any infringement on these rights.

The author argues that property rights should be assigned based on an individual's actions or inactions in relation to the owned asset. This is known as the homesteading principle, which is considered the foundation of property rights ethics. The author suggests that by implementing a pure private property society, it would lead to quicker economic recovery for Eastern Europe, as the population would become rich and the country would attract investors. The author also suggests that the production of security, such as police protection and a judicial system, would be taken over by Western insurance companies if government monopolization did not prevent it. The abolition of all price controls, wage controls, and import/export restrictions would promote economic growth and increase output, but temporarily increase unemployment.

The text discusses the economics of competitive private security production. The author notes that the influx of small entrepreneurs from Western Europe into an unregulated private property economy in Eastern Europe would be attractive due to the heavy tax burden and regulations in Western Europe. This would lead to a rapidly accelerating process of capital accumulation, and many Western Europeans would abandon welfare socialism for the unlimited opportunities offered in the East.

However, the actual course of desocialization in Eastern Europe since 1989 has proceeded differently than what was proposed. The size of Eastern European governments is still overwhelming and government personnel consists largely of the same individuals as before 1989, who are familiar with welfare-statist notions but unfamiliar with classical-liberal and libertarian ideas. If all collective property were privatized, all government jobs would disappear, but if the familiar Western European welfare-state model were adopted, most bureaucratic jobs could be secured and government revenue and salaries could increase.

In the postscript, the author notes that the method of privatization must be different in Western welfare states and in former socialist countries. The syndicalist privatization strategy applied only in cases where no previously expropriated private owner or heir existed, and if such an owner-heir could be identified, they should be reinstated as private owner.

The author argues that to privatize production factors, the ownership claim must have an objective foundation. The method of privatization must be different in socialism and welfare states. Privatizing through the civil servants is indefensible and has no real foundation. Taxpayers, who financed public buildings and structures, should be given title to them. Civil servants and welfare recipients, who live off other people's taxes, should be excluded from private ownership. In order to determine the ownership shares in buildings and structures currently owned by governments, individuals would need to provide documentation of their past tax payments, and past welfare payments received must be deducted from taxes paid.

In a fully privatized market society, private accountants, lawyers and arbitration agencies would be responsible for resolving the issue of ownership shares granted to individuals in buildings and structures currently owned by governments. To determine these ownership shares, individuals must provide documentation of their past payments of taxes and welfare receivables, which must then be used to calculate net taxes paid. These agencies are typically funded directly or indirectly by individual claimants without any contingency.

header: 7: On Free Immigration and Forced Integration
content:
The author of the book argues that the traditional argument in favor of free immigration is irrefutable and should not be attacked, but it also has two interrelated shortcomings; firstly, what constitutes wealth and well-being is subjective, and secondly, the issue of who owns or controls the territory into which people are immigrating is left unanalyzed. The author argues that if the assumption that the territory is unowned is dropped, the problem of immigration takes on an entirely new meaning and requires fundamental rethinking. The author then uses the concept of an anarcho-capitalist society as a benchmark to explain the fundamental misconception of most contemporary free immigration advocates.

The author argues that in a society where all land is privately owned, including streets, airports, harbors, rivers, etc., the freedom of immigration does not exist. Individual property owners have the freedom to admit or exclude others based on their unrestricted or restricted property titles. This leads to as much immigration, inclusivity, desegregation, or discrimination as individual owners or owner associations allow. However, this does not mean that there is a rejection of free trade, as the absolute voluntariness of human association and separation makes possible peaceful relationships and free trade between different groups. The author also notes that no multicultural society has ever worked peacefully for very long.

The distinction between "inlanders" (domestic citizens) and foreigners only arises with the establishment of a government, which possesses a territorial monopoly of aggression (taxation). In an anarcho-capitalist society, there is no government and hence no distinction between inlanders and foreigners. The existence of state borders and passports implies a two-fold distortion with respect to people's natural inclination to associate with others. First, inlanders cannot exclude the government from their own property and are subject to forced integration by government agents. Second, the government must have control of existing roads to access private property for taxation purposes, leading to overproduction of roads and forced domestic integration.

Even though Switzerland has an assembly of different ethnicities like German, French, Italian and Romansh, the country is not an exception to the rule. All important powers in the country, including the power to determine cultural and educational matters, are in the hands of the cantons rather than the central government. Most of the 26 cantons are ethnically homogeneous and only a few are bilingual. Despite these favorable circumstances, Switzerland experienced an unsuccessful, violently suppressed war of secession in 1847 known as the Sonderbundskrieg. The creation of the French-speaking canton of Jura from the predominantly German canton of Bern in 1979 was also preceded by years of terrorism. If a government is privately owned, the ruler-owner would choose immigration and emigration policies that preserve or enhance the value of his kingdom. A king would want to prevent the emigration of productive subjects and expel non-productive and destructive ones. He would also want to keep the mob and people of inferior productive capabilities out but permit the permanent immigration of superior or at least above-average people.

The author argues that the migration policies of a king and a democracy differ significantly. A king would be highly selective and concerned about improving the quality of the residents so as to drive property values up, while democratic rulers tend to maximize current income, which they can appropriate privately, at the expense of capital values, which they cannot appropriate privately. Hence, in accordance with democracy's inherent egalitarianism, democratic rulers tend to pursue a distinctly egalitarian, non-discriminatory emigration and immigration policy. The author argues that this policy of non-discrimination leads to forced integration, where masses of inferior immigrants are forced onto domestic property owners. The author cites the United States immigration laws of 1965 as an example of democracy at work.

The difference between monarchical and democratic-republican governments when it comes to emigration policy is not about being restrictive or unrestricted, but about the type of restrictions and the motivations behind them. Monarchical restrictions were motivated by economic concerns, while democratic-republican restrictions are typically motivated by power concerns, such as one's compulsory military service. France, with the longest democratic-republican tradition, had the most liberal immigration and naturalization policy among major European countries. The author cites various works that discuss immigration and multiculturalism in the U.S., including the impact on the economy and the welfare state, and the changing demographics of the country. Brimelow documents that from 1820 until 1967, 90% of immigrants to the U.S. were of European descent, while 85% of the close to 17 million legal immigrants from 1967 to 1993 came from the Third World, mostly Latin America and Asia. The current influx of legal and illegal immigrants is concentrated in a few regions and metropolitan areas, making assimilation unlikely. A study by the National Academy of Sciences found that immigration raised taxes for the typical native household in California by $1,200 per year. The immigration policy of a democracy reflects its policy toward internal population movements, promoting forced integration through nondiscrimination laws. This is because democratic rulers, concerned with their current income and power and constrained by egalitarian sentiments, want to increase physical access to everyone's property. The author argues that the so-called "civil rights" legislation in the U.S., which mandated forced integration, coincided with the adoption of a nondiscriminatory immigration policy, which mandated international desegregation (forced integration).

The author suggests that ethnicity plays a significant role in economic life. Immigrants tend to move to ethnic ghettos, which incubates ethnic differences, causing the skill differential between the native and immigrant population to persist for three generations. The author argues that the current immigration situation in the United States and Western Europe is not free immigration, but forced integration. Abolishing forced integration requires the abolition of democracy, and the power to admit or exclude should be given back to the states, cities, towns, and ultimately to private property owners and their voluntary associations. The best immigration policy under a democratic central state would be to act as if the rulers were personal owners of the country, following a policy of strict discrimination towards skill, character, and cultural compatibility. This implies requiring personal sponsorship, an employment contract with a resident citizen, and tests on intellectual performance and character structure, with a systematic pro-European immigration bias.

header: 8: On Free Trade and Restricted Immigration
content:
In this chapter, the author argues that free trade and restricted immigration are not only consistent but mutually reinforcing policies. He debunks the popular belief that free trade is connected with free immigration and protectionism with restricted immigration. The author starts by summarizing the case for free trade made by economists such as Ricardo and Bastiat. The main argument advanced in favor of protectionism is that it protects domestic jobs from foreign competition. However, the author argues that this argument is fallacious and leads to absurd implications if taken to its logical conclusion. The same argument can be made for interregional and interlocal protectionism, which would lead to poverty and destitution. The author concludes that free trade and restricted immigration are not only consistent but also mutually reinforcing policies as they promote prosperity and strength.

The author argues that freedom of trade should be considered a fundamental axiom of political economy. While investigations into the state of trade and causes of present depression are welcomed, it is not expected for opinions on free trade to be altered by such investigations as axioms cannot be disproved. The author believes that international protectionism would have the same negative effects as interpersonal or interregional protectionism and lead to America's further economic decline. American jobs and industries may be saved, but the standard of living and real income of American consumers of foreign products would be reduced. The cost of all United States producers who use the protected industry's products as input factors would increase and they would become less competitive internationally. 

Another author, Rothbard, offers a reductio ad absurdum of the protectionist thesis by using an example of a farm where a 1000 percent tariff is levied on imports from outside the farm. The result is a bare subsistence instead of a comfortable standard of living due to a drastic reduction in the real value of wages. Rothbard also points out that the proponents of fair trade do not address why U.S. wage rates are higher than in other countries in the first place. The author argues that if the American wage is twice that of another country, it is because the American laborer is more heavily capitalized and equipped with better tools, making them more productive. Confusing the price of labor with its cost leads to protectionist fallacies. By imposing protective tariffs and quotas, the protectionists harm both American consumers and efficient American firms and industries.

The author argues that the claim that England's loss of its former preeminence was due to its free trade policies is nonsense. Instead, England lost its position because of the socialist policies which took hold in England during the late 19th century. The United States also attained its economic preeminence not because of its protectionist policies, but because of its internal laissez-faire policies. America's current economic decline is not due to its alleged free trade policies, but to the fact that it adopted the same socialist policies that ruined England earlier. The relationship between trade and migration is elastic, with more trade leading to less migration and vice versa. The foreign trade policy of a nation affects immigration, as well as its domestic trade policy, with strict domestic free trade reducing immigration while social welfare policies increase it. The author references economists such as Ludwig von Mises and Murray Rothbard to support his arguments.

The author argues that the immigration pressure from low-wage countries will be reduced if a high-wage area such as the United States engages in unrestricted free trade, and will become more pressing if the country implements protectionist policies and welfare programs. He points out that North America and Western Europe are currently facing an increase of immigration pressure and are trying to find a way to deal with it. Three strategies have been proposed: unconditional free immigration, conditional free immigration, and restrictive immigration. The author believes that the unconditional free immigration policy is intellectually bankrupt and irresponsible, and that it would result in disastrous consequences if implemented. He also critiques the United States' free trade and domestic welfare records, stating that the country has a labyrinthine system of tariffs and regulations, as well as a high level of welfare assistance, making it vulnerable to an influx of immigrants.

The author cites Julian L. Simon's position on immigration and argues that Simon does not advocate an open-door policy, despite the fact that some individuals and institutions refer to him as their patron saint in this regard. Instead, Simon recommends increasing immigration quotas in increments of half a percent or one percent at each step, so as to check for any unexpected negative consequences. He suggests weeding out potential immigrants who will become a welfare burden and recommends discrimination in favor of educated immigrants who demonstrate proficiency in English. He also suggests giving preference to applicants with financial assets capable of making a direct investment in the host country and is fond of the idea of selling the right of immigration to the highest bidders. 

Walter Block stakes out a truly remarkable position on immigration, advocating an open-door policy despite its predictable consequences. He argues that such a stand is required by the principles of libertarian political philosophy, but the author disagrees and explains why libertarianism does not require an open-door policy. 

According to surveys conducted during the early 1990s in the former Soviet Union, over 30% of the population expressed the desire to emigrate, while the 1997 lottery held by the U.S. attracted 3.4 million applicants for just 50,000 visas. The author argues that unconditional free immigration must be regarded as a prescription for societal suicide, but the typical position among free traders is conditional free immigration. However, this view is erroneous and harmful, as it reduces but does not eliminate immigration pressure, and there is no analogy between free trade and free immigration. People can move and migrate, whereas goods and services cannot.

The author argues that there is a fundamental difference between public property and unowned goods. Public property is de facto owned by the taxpaying members of the domestic public and therefore, bums who have not paid taxes nor foreigners who have not paid domestic taxes cannot be assumed to have any rights regarding public property. The distinction between immigration and trade is crucial, as while goods and services can only be shipped with both sender and receiver agreeing, someone can migrate without anyone else wanting them to do so. This distinction leads to the argument that while free trade means trade by invitation of private households and firms, free immigration does not mean immigration by invitation of individual households and firms, but unwanted invasion or forced integration. The author argues that for a high-wage area government to fulfill its primary function as the protector of its citizens and their domestic property, it cannot follow a policy of laissez-passer, but must engage in restrictive measures. The guiding principle of a high-wage area country's immigration policy must be that immigration must be invited, just like trade.

The author argues that in a private property anarchy, anarcho-capitalism, or ordered anarchy, all land is privately owned and the owner has the freedom to admit or exclude others from their own property. In this kind of society, there is no freedom of immigration or an immigrant's right-of-way. Instead, it is up to individual property owners to decide whether to admit or exclude others. This concept is compared to the current situation of open borders in the US, which is a compulsory opening imposed by the central state, not the proprietors. The anarcho-capitalist model highlights what a government's immigration policy would have to be if it derived its legitimacy from the sovereignty of the people and was viewed as an agreement or social contract between the government and citizens. The author believes that such a popular government would want to preserve the no-forced integration feature of anarcho-capitalism, where all movements of immigrants into and within an anarcho-capitalist society are the result of an agreement between the immigrant and one or more receiving domestic property owners.

The distinction between inlanders and foreigners only appears with the establishment of a government. The government, as the domestic security-producer monopolist, ultimately has the decision of whether or not a person should be admitted into the country. The larger the amount of public property, the greater the potential problem of forced integration. The Soviet Union and East Germany were socialist countries, where all factors of production were publicly owned and forced integration was spread everywhere. In non-socialist countries, an immigrant's freedom of movement would be restricted by private property and land ownership, but he can move into virtually any neighborhood through public roads and public parks. A popular government that wants to prevent forced integration has two methods: a corrective method, which reduces the quantity of public property and expands that of private property, and a preventive method, which checks all newly arriving persons for an entrance ticket from a domestic property owner.

The author argues that immigration should be made into a contractual agreement between the host and the immigrant. The invitation can be private or commercial, temporary or permanent, and may include housing and employment. However, a contract for employment without housing is not valid. The host has the right to revoke the invitation at any time, and the invitee becomes a permanent resident only upon acquiring citizenship. Citizenship is acquired by purchasing residential property from a citizen resident. The Swiss government's immigration policy is deemed better than the United States' but still too permissive.

The author argues that the permissive immigration policies in Switzerland and the United States, along with other high-wage areas, have resulted in forced integration and rising popular protests. This is exacerbated by the substantial extent of public property, high tax-funded welfare provisions, and limited adherence to free trade policies. The chapter's goal is to make a case for privatizing public property, promoting domestic laissez-faire, adopting a restrictive immigration policy, and ensuring migration is subject to invitation and contractual agreement.

header: 9: On Cooperation, Tribe, City, and State
content:
The chapter discusses the evolution of human cooperation and the formation of society, which is explained by Ludwig von Mises as being a result of two factors: differences among men (in terms of labor) and/or inequalities in the geographical distribution of natural resources (land), and the recognition of the fact that work performed under the division of labor is more productive than work performed in self-sufficient isolation. The author emphasizes that inequalities with respect to labor and/or land are necessary but not sufficient conditions for the emergence of human cooperation. To bring about cooperation, two people must recognize the higher productivity of a division of labor based on mutual recognition of private property (the exclusive control of every man over his own body and possessions) as compared to self-sufficient isolation or aggression, depredation, and domination. A minimum level of intelligence or rationality and moral strength is also required for this cooperation to evolve. Without intelligence and conscious will, men would have remained deadly foes and rivals for access to scarce resources, unable to develop sympathy for one another.

According to Mises, the reason why human cooperation and society exists is due to our ability to rationalize and make choices that are in line with social cooperation. People are capable of understanding the advantages of a division of labor based on private property but may lack the moral strength to act accordingly. Those who are unable to understand this are considered like animals, either harmless or dangerous. Society can only advance as long as man is capable of suppressing crime and protecting property through self-defense and punishment. In a society based on cooperation, people can transform their natural tendencies and impulses into social relationships. For example, sexual attraction can lead to consensual relations and love, whereas interracial repulsion can lead to indirect cooperation. The feelings of sympathy and friendship emerge from social cooperation, but they do not bring about social relationships. Mises explains that mutual sexual attraction between men and women leads to integrated family households and that the division of labor based on geographical allocation of physical approximation and integration leads to improved standards of living.

The text explains that the division of labor and increased diversity and differentiation are linked to human cooperation and improved standards of living. These developments lead to the emergence of merchants, trading centers, and cities as the mediators of indirect exchanges between households and communities. The merchant class is where racially, ethnically, or tribally mixed marriages are most common and is typically more wealthy, contributing to genetic luxuration. In big cities, members of different ethnicities and races come into regular contact with each other and develop highly refined forms of personal and professional conduct and etiquette. The human family is not a product of sexual intercourse but is a result of thinking, planning, and acting. The significance of race and ethnicity and genetic similarity and dissimilarity are explored by authors such as J. Philippe Rushton and Michael Levin. The text also mentions that peaceful racial or ethnic mixing is typically restricted to members of the social upper-class and the leading royal dynasties. The great trading centers, like Antioch during the Islamic civilization, developed complex patterns of spatial separation and functional integration, with different quarters divided by race and religion.

The author explains the formation of a government in a city and how it can lead to interracial, tribal, ethnic, and clannish tensions. A single judge can become a monopolist by playing the "race card," increasing racial, tribal, or clanish consciousness among citizens of their own group and promising to be more impartial in matters concerning their own race, tribe, or clan. When a monopolist tries to maintain their position, the form of government is often a democratic republic instead of a monarchy because large commercial cities with ethnically mixed populations are unlikely to have royal or princely rule. The author also cites Max Weber's work on the sociological proposition that the first experiments with democratic-republican forms of government occurred in cities that broke off and gained independence from their predominantly monarchical and rural surroundings.

The author argues that the consequences of the judicial monopoly of governments can be observed in the decline of great cities due to forced integration and segregation caused by the centralization of government. The central government must control roads in order to exercise its judicial monopoly, forcing different households into closer contact. The result is a forced integration of city and countryside. This tendency towards integration is most pronounced in cities and is further stimulated if the government takes its seat in a city, as redistributive policies will attract more people from different ethnicities to the capital. 

Interethnic marriages and sexual relationships will also increase, leading to increased genetic pauperization, particularly among the lower classes who receive welfare support. The character of democratic government will change as well, as politics becomes increasingly focused on social class rather than ethnicity or race. The increasing admixture of egalitarian class politics leads to even more racial and social tensions and an even greater proliferation of the low and underclass population. Upper-class members will leave the city for the suburbs, weakening the last remaining civilizing force in the cities. The population left behind in the cities will be increasingly negative, consisting of government bureaucrats who work but no longer live there and lowlifes and social outcasts who live on welfare.

The author contrasts plebeian government to patrician government and notes the differences in their concept of law. In the medieval city states of Europe, the establishment of rule by the popolo led to an increased number of laws and officials. The political justice of the popolo system was characterized by exclusion of certain members from office, obligations for notables, and a special criminal law for political offenses of magnates. The establishment of a government also implies the integration of formerly separated jurisdictions and the dissolution of formerly fully integrated jurisdictions within households and families. Government welfare lowers the value of a person's membership in a family and leads to family disintegration. The government's ability to interfere in family matters is seen as the ultimate prize for its rulers, leading to an increase in divorce, single parenting, and nontraditional lifestyles.

The text discusses the state of Western civilization and the reasons for its decline. The author argues that the trend towards monopolistic law enforcement and redistributive policies have eroded the concept of justice, leading to increased crime rates and moral decay. The welfare state is seen as promoting the proliferation of intellectually and morally inferior people, and it is suggested that the genetic quality of the population has declined. The author believes there are still pockets of civilization and culture in rural areas, but in order to preserve them several requirements must be met, including recognizing the family as the source of civilization, reasserting the authority of families as judges in internal affairs, and recognizing welfare as a matter of voluntary charity. The author also suggests that the decline in intelligence may have contributed to the decline of Western civilization.

Hans Hermann Hoppe in his book Democracy the God that Failed, explains the two possible meanings of the term "conservative". The first meaning is to refer to someone who supports the status quo, whereas the second meaning refers to someone who believes in the existence of a natural order. The author argues that the second definition is the true meaning of conservatism and explains that it refers to someone who recognizes the old and natural order through the anomalies and accidents and who defends, supports, and helps preserve it against the temporary and anomalous. Western Greco-Christian conservatives stand for preserving the family and the social hierarchies and layers of material as well as spiritual-intellectual authority based on and growing out of family bonds and kinship relations.

The author then evaluates contemporary conservatism and argues that it is confused and distorted, largely due to democracy. Under the influence of representative democracy, conservatism was transformed from an anti-egalitarian, aristocratic, anti-statist ideology into a culturally conservative statist movement. Most contemporary conservatives are concerned about the decay of families, divorce, and other social problems, but they are not antistatist and do not understand the true meaning of conservatism.

The author argues that conservatives today must be anti-statist libertarians and that libertarians must be conservatives. He believes that a true conservative should defend private property, families, and social hierarchies based on voluntary agreements and that a true libertarian should recognize the importance of preserving the natural order and the traditional institutions that have been developed over time.

The author argues that contemporary conservatism, particularly in Europe and the U.S., has been distorted by democracy and has become a movement of culturally conservative statists who are unable to recognize the need for drastic changes to restore normalcy. The conservative emphasis on family, authority, and social rank orders can be traced back to the historic affinity between family and property. For the conservative, preservation of property and liberty requires the existence of a natural elite or aristocracy, making the conservative strictly opposed to democracy. The author also critiques the fundamental statism of contemporary American conservatism and calls out the so-called neoconservatives for promoting global social democracy under the guise of cultural conservatism. In comparison, the author claims that there is not a trace of principled antistatism in either the conservative Republican party establishment or the conservatism represented by Patrick Buchanan and his movement.

William Buckley and his National Review played a significant role in promoting a new form of conservatism after World War II. Unlike the pre-World War II American conservatism, the new conservatism was characterized by militarism and interventionist foreign policy, which was advocated by Buckley in light of the threat posed by the Soviet Union. He believed that the government needed to be big to wage war, including having large armies, air forces, intelligence services, and war production boards. This philosophy has not changed much since the collapse of the Soviet Union, with new and neo-conservatives continuing to promote the welfare-warfare state as a means of dealing with other perceived foreign enemies like China and Islamic fundamentalism. Robert Nisbet, a contemporary of Buckley, noted that this type of conservatism is not representative of the traditional conservatism seen in America throughout the 20th century.

Samuel Francis, a leading strategist of the Buchananite movement, proposed a new spirit of "America First," which would prioritize national interests over other nations and abstractions like the "New World Order." However, he did not recognize that moral degeneracy and cultural rot have deeper causes than simply changes in state curriculum or exhortations. He also defended the three core institutions of the welfare state, including social security, medicare, and unemployment subsidies. Buchanan and his intellectual allies want to abolish federal control over education and return it to the states or local government, while others simply desire to replace the current left-liberal elite in charge of national education with themselves. Robert Nisbet criticized this posture, pointing out that giving the government control over family functions weakens the family.

A social nationalism or national socialism is a type of conservatism that combines the economic policies of the left with the nationalism and cultural conservativism of the right. This view is not popular among traditional conservatives and they argue that it is impossible to maintain the current level of economic socialism and reach the goal of restoring cultural normalcy (natural families and normal rules of conduct). The author questions whether cultural conservatism and social-socialist economics can be effectively combined, considering the fact that the core institutions of the present welfare state are incompatible with the goal of returning to traditional families, norms, conduct, and culture. The author cites the view of an economist who states that all compulsory wealth or income redistribution will necessarily involve taking from some and giving to others, thereby reducing the incentive to be a haver and increasing the incentive to be a non-haver.

The author argues that the system of social security, which provides insurance against old age, illness, unemployment, and indigence, implemented in Western Europe and the US, is a massive attack on the institution of the family and personal responsibility. By relieving individuals of the obligation to provide for their own income, health, safety, old age and children's education, it reduces the range and temporal horizon of private provision, lowers the value of marriage, family, children and kinship relations, and promotes irresponsibility, shortsightedness, and negligence. The compulsory old age insurance system, where retirees are subsidized by taxes imposed on current income earners, has systematically weakened the natural intergenerational bond between parents, grandparents and children. This has resulted in fewer children being born and a reduced respect for elders. The system has also led to an increase in the rates of divorce, illegitimacy, child abuse, parent abuse, spouse abuse, single parenting, and alternative lifestyles.

The author also argues that the socialization of the health care system through institutions like Medicaid and Medicare, and the regulation of the insurance industry, has put in motion a machinery of wealth and income redistribution that favors irresponsible actors and high-risk groups at the expense of responsible individuals and low-risk groups. This system has weakened the desire to work for a living and lead healthy lives.

The author critiques protectionist policies as economic destructionism, arguing that such policies would not result in prosperity and strength but poverty and starvation. The idea that everyone would be better off if they never traded with anyone else is described as economic nonsense.

The author argues that the welfare state is responsible for the moral degeneration and cultural decay. Old-style conservatives opposed public education and social security because they believed these policies would lead to increased control by the state and a systematic infantilization of society. The author argues that true conservatives must be radical libertarians and demand the elimination of the entire structure of social security. Most contemporary conservatives are not actually conservatives but socialists, either of the internationalist or nationalist variety. The term libertarianism as used in the text refers to a post-World War II phenomenon with roots in classical liberalism and natural law philosophy. It is a rational system of ethics culminating in the work of Murray N. Rothbard.

The author explains that libertarianism is a systematic law code, derived from a single ethical axiom. The axiom is the principle of original appropriation, which states that ownership of scarce resources or private property is acquired through an act of original appropriation. From this principle, rules concerning the transformation and transfer of originally appropriated resources are derived, and all of ethics (law) is reconstructed in terms of a theory of property rights. The author believes that the libertarian law code is irrefutably true. The relationship between libertarianism and conservatism is one of compatibility, complementarity, and reciprocal reinforcement. The author argues in favor of the validity of the principle of original appropriation using a logical deduction process and concludes that it is the only viable option for a just rule.

The author argues that ethical problems arise from conflict between separate and independent agents with respect to scarce means or goods. Ethics concerns the assignment of property rights over scarce goods to rule out conflict. Conflicts involving gorillas or mosquitoes do not give rise to ethical problems as they only pose a technical problem. Only if both parties to a conflict are capable of prepositional exchange, i.e., argumentation, can one speak of an ethical problem. The author's impossibility theorem states that the common rationality as displayed by the ability to engage in propositional exchange constitutes a necessary condition for ethical problems and that the mutual recognition of the principle of original appropriation by both parties is the praxeological presupposition of argumentation. The author also points out that most leading libertarian thinkers were social cultural conservatives and that the conservative and the libertarian views of society are compatible and share a fundamental respect. The author argues that the libertarian ethic is not new and revolutionary but old and conservative, even primitives and children are capable of grasping the validity of the principle of original appropriation.

The author mentions the relationship between conservatism and libertarianism, noting that while the intellectual creators of modern libertarianism were cultural conservatives, the movement has become culturally leftist due to a misunderstanding of the doctrine and the influence of the welfare state on society. The beginning of the modern libertarian movement in the U.S. can be traced back to the mid-1960s, when the Libertarian party was founded. The rise of the movement coincided with the growth of the welfare state and the emergence of a new "Lumpenproletariat" of intellectuals who were "alienated" from mainstream culture and values. This group embraced multiculturalism, cultural relativism and antiauthoritarianism. The author argues that this form of libertarianism is false and counterproductive.

The libertarian opposition to the Vietnam War coincided with the opposition of the New Left, and the anarchistic aspect of the libertarian doctrine appealed to the countercultural left. The libertarian movement attracted an abnormal number of followers from the beginning, who were drawn to the idea of a society where everyone was free to live as they pleased, without interference from the state. This countercultural atmosphere also drew in misfits, personal or professional failures, or plain losers. However, the alliance between the New Left and the fledgling libertarian movement during the mid-1960s was motivated by the New Left's opposition to the Vietnam War and imperialism and its semi-anarchistic positions, which appeared to be a thoroughgoing opposition to the existing welfare-warfare post-New Deal corporate state and the state-ridden bureaucratic university system. 

Later, Rothbard acknowledged that his attempt to forge an alliance between libertarians and the New Left was a strategic error, as he had overestimated the emotional stability and knowledge of economics of the fledgling libertarians and underestimated the significance of them being weak and isolated. He also painted a portrait of the "modal libertarian," who was typically in their forties, fairly bright, and well-versed in libertarian theory, but knew little about history, culture, or world affairs. The modal libertarian was an adolescent rebel who opposed institutions of social and cultural authority and was drawn to Randianism as a way to rationalize rejection of their family, neighbors, and society at large. The modal libertarian's occupation was often a computer programmer and they were known for their fanatical behavior.

The author argues that the combination of private property capitalism and egalitarian multiculturalism is unlikely to succeed. The modern libertarian movement has failed to recognize this and has actually contributed to the erosion of private property rights. True libertarians must be radical and uncompromising conservatives, embracing discrimination and promoting the enforcement of private property rights. This means that social "discrimination" will increase, and many multicultural-egalitarian experiments will be eliminated. The left libertarians represented by institutions like the Cato Institute and the Institute for Justice are misguided in their efforts to seek the assistance of the central government in enforcing policies of nondiscrimination and advocating for a free immigration policy. The author argues that left-libertarians (LLs) employ and promote the use of the federal government and its courts to suppress discriminatory state and local laws and regulations, thus contributing to the growth of the central state and the diminution of private property rights. LLs also have a distinct concern for civil rights, but this leads them to accept the principle of nondiscrimination, which contributes to the aggrandizement of state power and the diminution of private property rights. The author argues that LLs commit the error of regarding public property as either unowned land or property open to every citizen, when in fact it has been financed by taxpayers and there is little that is genuinely private and not subject to government control.

According to the text, the modern welfare state has limited private property owners' rights to exclusion. This leads to forced integration where people are not able to choose who they associate with, and this has resulted in a lack of personal and physical protection, increased ill-behavior and uncivilized social relations. On the other hand, restoring the right of exclusion would result in a highly discriminatory society, but it would also restore the freedom of association. This would lead to cultural and moral normalcy. The views on this topic have been rebutted from a "paleo-libertarian" perspective by Murray N Rothbard, who believes that private property owners should have the absolute right to discriminate and exclude whomever they please.

The text describes the consequences of free market communities in which private property rights are enforced. Left-libertarians and countercultural individuals would have to pay a price for their behavior if it does not align with the moral and cultural norms of the society they want to enter. They would either be barred from society or have to adjust their behavior to the norms. If they choose to assimilate, their alternative behavior would have to stay hidden from public view. The predicted rise in discrimination in a libertarian world would mean that there would be a great variety of locally separated communities engaging in different forms of exclusion or expulsion. Each community would have to enforce strict limitations on its internal tolerance for the sake of self-preservation. The author asserts that true conservative libertarians must recognize and appreciate the importance of strict discrimination to maintain a private property anarchy. The standard libertarian model of community is too simplistic, as neighborhoods can also involve risks and lead to falling property values. In reality, communities have formed along different lines to overcome the difficulties posed by divided ownership.

Previously, neighborhoods were typically proprietary or covenantal communities that were founded and owned by a single proprietor. Originally, these covenants were based on kinship relations, with the head of a family or clan serving as the proprietor. In modern times, however, the original libertarian model of a proprietary community has been replaced by developments such as shopping malls and gated communities, which are owned by an individual or private corporation. The proprietor is an entrepreneur who seeks profits from developing and managing residential and/or business communities. The proprietor builds value in the inventory of community land by satisfying three functional requirements: selection of members, land planning, and leadership. The proprietor automatically fulfills the first two functions, membership selection and land planning, by determining to whom and for what purpose to lease the use of land. The proprietor is also responsible for providing leadership, which includes arbitration of differences among tenants and ensuring the security of the community. The proprietary community is not unique to modern times and has roots deep in human history.

The text describes the traditional way of administering land ownership, which is commonly through a senior male member of the kin group. This system is called seignorialism, where the distributive authority is exercised by the senior member of the kin group. The task of maintaining the covenant in a proprietary community is primarily the responsibility of the proprietor. However, he needs the support of the majority of the community members, particularly the heads of households and firms heavily invested in the community. Both the proprietor and the community elite must be willing to defend themselves against external invaders and domestic criminals through physical force and punishment. They must also be willing to defend themselves against those who advocate incompatible actions with the purpose of the covenant through ostracism, exclusion, and expulsion. Ownership organized as participation in a single property leads to a common interest in redeveloping and managing it as a unit in the most productive way. The community always faces the threat of egalitarianism and cultural relativism, which are incompatible with private property and families and intergenerational kinship relations. The enforcement of a covenant is largely a matter of prudence, requiring judgment on the part of the members of the community. The situation may require drastic measures if moral relativism and egalitarianism have taken hold among adult members of society.

The text is discussing the idea of exclusion and tolerance in a free society. According to the author, members of a covenant that protects private property must act decisively to exclude those who advocate ideas such as democracy or communism that are contrary to the purpose of the covenant. In order to establish a free social order, libertarians must be moral and cultural conservatives and practice the most extreme form of intolerance and discrimination against those who promote egalitarian sentiments. The current state of moral decay and cultural rot is due to too much tolerance of these types of attitudes. Libertarians must regain the right to exclusion from the state and exercise this right in everyday life. They should distinguish themselves from other groups by advocating for intolerance and discrimination against egalitarians, democrats, socialists, and other groups that promote non-conservative lifestyles and attitudes.

header: 11: On the Errors of Classical Liberalism and the Future of Liberty
content:
Hans Hermann Hoppe argues in the chapter "On the Errors of Classical Liberalism and the Future of Liberty" that classical liberalism has been on a decline for more than a century, with public affairs being shaped increasingly by socialist ideas. The author notes that the term "liberalism" has taken on an opposite meaning, tracing it back to John Stuart Mill's 1859 book On Liberty, which is considered the fountainhead of moderate socialism. The author points out that even if there were some periods of liberalization, such as in West Germany and Italy after World War II and Eastern Europe after the collapse of the Soviet Empire, these were not indicative of a renaissance of liberalism. Rather, they were the result of external and accidental events, such as military defeat and/or economic bankruptcy, and the subsequent liberalization was simply a variant of socialism. The author concludes that even if social democracy will eventually collapse economically, there is no reason to assume that this will lead to a liberal renaissance.

The discussion focuses on the issue of liberalism and its central error in the political theory. The author notes that the socialist transformation of the last hundred years is a result of liberalism's philosophical defeat as a political doctrine. The author argues that the rejection of liberalism is not due to public indolence or degeneracy, but rather an error in the liberal doctrine itself. The author believes that the central error lies in the theory of government. According to Rothbard's The Ethics of Liberty and Hoppe's The Economics and Ethics of Private Property, classical liberal political philosophy was based on moral principles such as self-ownership, property rights, and contract. This political philosophy centered on universal human rights, which were inherent in the nature of man as a rational animal.

The liberal philosophy viewed every person, whether king or peasant, as subject to the same universal and eternal principles of justice. This placed it in opposition to established governments in an environment of princely and royal rulers. The affirmative liberal answer to government was that it was necessary to maintain law and order by having members press criminals to respect the life and property of others, with the task of maintaining order being the unique function of government. However, liberals believed that government must possess a compulsory territorial monopoly of jurisdiction and the right to tax, which is incompatible with the rightful protection of property. According to liberal doctrine, private property rights precede any government and arise from acts of original appropriation, production, and/or exchange. No private property owner can surrender their right to ultimate jurisdiction over their property unless they sell or transfer it. Property owners can seek protection through cooperation with other owners and may buy or contract with individuals or agencies for protection services.

The text discusses the liberal position on government and private property as expressed by Mercier de la Riviere. According to Riviere, man is capable of recognizing the laws that lead to his greatest happiness and all social ills stem from disregarding these laws of human nature. The right of self-preservation implies the right to property, and individual property in man's products from the soil requires property in the land itself. But the right to property would be meaningless without the freedom of using it, so liberty is derived from the right to property, and people flourish and maximize happiness through trade and exchange of property.

The text then critiques the idea of a monopoly contract where private property owners would surrender their right to decision-making and protection of their person and property permanently to another agent. This type of contract is considered null and void because it contradicts the praxeological foundation of all contracts, i.e., private property and individual self-ownership. It is considered impossible for individuals to agree to render themselves permanently defenseless or for anyone to endow their protector with the permanent right to tax.

The author also critiques the contract theory of the state, which originated with Thomas Hobbes. Hobbes claimed that the legal bond between the ruler and the subjects, once it has been tied, is indissoluble. However, most influential writers in the seventeenth century rejected Hobbes' conclusions and charged him with a contradiction in terms. They believed that if a man could give up his right to self-ownership, he would cease being a moral being and would become a lifeless thing, incapable of making promises or entering into social contracts.

Liberals have attempted to solve the internal contradiction through the makeshift of "tacit," "implicit" or "conceptual" agreements, contracts, or constitutions, but these attempts have only contributed to the conclusion that it is impossible to derive a justification for government from explicit contracts between private property owners. The author also mentions John Locke's views on "consent," according to which every man that has any possession or enjoyment of any part of the dominions of any government gives his tacit consent and is obliged to obey the laws of that government during such enjoyment. According to Locke, once a government has come into existence, regardless of whether one has expressly agreed to its rule in the first place or not, one has "tacitly" consented to it and whatever it does as long as one continues to live in "its" territory.

James M. Buchanan and Gordon Tullock's attempt to justify the government as a voluntary institution on par with private business firms is considered absurd. According to Hoppe, liberalism's acceptance of the institution of government as consistent with self-ownership, original appropriation, property and contract led to its own destruction. In the eyes of Hoppe, the idea of a limited government is a contradictory, praxeologically impossible ideal. Every minimal government has the inherent tendency to become a maximal one, since once the principle of government is accepted as just, any notion of restraining government power and safeguarding individual liberty and property is illusory. The price of justice and protection will continually rise under monopolistic auspices and the quality of justice and protection will fall, as the government agent's goal will be to maximize expenditures on protection and minimize the production of protection. A judicial monopoly will inevitably lead to a steady deterioration in the quality of protection. The definition of property and protection will continually be altered and the range of jurisdiction expanded to the government's advantage.

The text discusses the government's allocation of limited funds for police protection and its tendency to centralize. The author argues that the traditional liberal preference for local government is inconsistent with the idea that the government must provide "police protection." The author also argues that if it is believed that a judicial monopolist is necessary for peaceful cooperation between two individuals, then the conclusion follows that all political centralization and ultimately a single world government are necessary. Additionally, the author claims that the idea of universal human rights is transformed into a vehicle of egalitarianism when combined with government, leading to the destruction of human rights. The author argues that democracy, in which everyone is permitted to become a government official, is incompatible with the idea of one universal law equally applicable to everyone.

The text discusses how democracy fails to preserve the idea of liberty and property. It argues that democracy, despite its principle of equality, still separates public and private law and gives public law supremacy over private law, leading to functional privileges and legal discrimination. The author claims that under democratic conditions, the tendency for monopolies to increase prices and decrease quality will become stronger, and exploitation will become less calculating and more shortsighted. The author also argues that democracy leads to the perversion of justice as it becomes a machine for the continual redistribution of property rights in the name of "social security." The author suggests that because of the fundamental error in accepting the moral status of government, liberalism has no future and will ultimately result in social democracy, which has already arrived but does not work.

The author argues that once the legitimacy of government is accepted, there is no moral case against increased taxation and redistribution. The liberal case for lower taxes is only an economic one, but cost-benefit analysis, which involves comparing utilities between individuals, is scientifically impermissible. Democrats appear more consistent and straightforward, while liberals appear starry-eyed and unprincipled. If liberalism is to have a future, it must repair its fundamental error by recognizing that governments cannot be contractually justified and that protection and security can only be produced by competitive security suppliers. This shift from liberalism to private property anarchism would purify and radicalize the liberal movement. The transition from liberalism to private property anarchism is a small intellectual step but has significant practical implications.

The author mentions Ludwig von Mises and his influence on the logical-theoretical affinity of classical liberalism and private property anarchism. Mises's best known students Friedrich A. Hayek and Murray N. Rothbard had different interpretations of Mises's theories. Hayek became Mises's student before he fully worked out his own intellectual system and would essentially become a moderate social democrat, while Rothbard became Mises's student after he had worked out his entire system and would become the theoretician of anarcho-capitalism. The majority of intellectuals who fully absorbed the work of Mises and Hayek and Rothbard have come to adopt Rothbard's revisions of the Misesian system as the logically consequent fulfillment of Mises's original intent. The new radicalism of the liberal movement proposes the decomposition of the nation state into its constituent parts and the unrestricted proliferation of independent free territories until the state's range of jurisdiction withers away. The vision being promoted is a world of tens of thousands of free countries, regions and cantons, with the smaller territories having greater economic pressure to opt for free trade, and an international gold-commodity money standard. The end of the social democratic "End of History" will give rise to a liberal renaissance if this alternative liberal vision gains prominence in public opinion. Jefferson and the American Declaration of Independence consider secession from a government's jurisdiction a basic human right and Ludwig von Mises, the 20th-century's foremost champion of liberalism, has been an outspoken proponent of the right to secede as implied in the most fundamental human right to self-determination.

Mises supports the idea of self-determination in regard to the question of membership in a state. He believes that if the inhabitants of a territory make it known, through a free plebiscite, that they no longer wish to remain part of a state, their wishes should be respected and complied with. Mises argues that this is the only feasible and effective way of avoiding revolutions and wars. By allowing unlimited secession, a government is no longer a compulsory monopolist of law and order but a voluntary association. Rothbard notes that once the right of secession exists, there is no logical stopping-point short of individual secession, which leads to anarchism as individuals can secede and patronize their own defense agencies.

header: 12: On Government and the Private Production of Defense
content:
Hans-Hermann Hoppe is critical of the belief in collective security, which he argues is a myth that provides no justification for the modern state. He argues that all security is and must be private. He explains that the Hobbesian myth of collective security is a view that originated from Thomas Hobbes who argued that in the state of nature, men would constantly be at each other's throats, leading to a permanent underproduction of security. The solution to this, according to Hobbes, is the establishment of a state. In order to institute peaceful cooperation among individuals, two people require a third independent party as a judge and peacemaker. However, this third party is not just another individual, but a sovereign with two unique powers. The first power is the ability to insist that his subjects not seek protection from anyone but him, making him a compulsory territorial monopolist of protection. The second power is the ability to determine how much the subjects must spend on their own defense.

Hoppe argues that the Hobbesian solution is problematic because regardless of how bad men are, the sovereign is still one of them, and man's nature is not transformed upon becoming the sovereign. In fact, Hoppe refers to the sovereign as a protection racket, as he will make peace between individuals so he can rob them more profitably. Further, Hoppe argues that the idea of a protective state coming about as the result of a constitutional contract is a fallacy, as no one would agree to a contract that allowed the protector to determine unilaterally how much the protected must pay.

He also discusses the two-fold conclusion that follows from the assumption that peace requires a state. If more than one state exists, then there can be no peace between them as long as they remain in a state of nature with each other. To achieve universal peace, political centralization, unification, and ultimately the establishment of a single world government are necessary.

The author argues that the notion of the state being indispensable for protection and defense is widely accepted, but may not be true. The evidence from the American experiment in protective statism does not support the Hobbesian claim. Despite the government's claims of better protection, the state continually expropriates a high percentage of the incomes of private producers and regulates every aspect of private life. This has resulted in increased financial insecurity and legal uncertainty, as well as the erosion of private property rights. The more the state has increased its expenditures on security, the more it has reduced private property rights and led to a decrease in personal wealth and economic independence, which are the foundations of protection.

The author argues that the U.S. government is not protective but harmful to life, property and prosperity of its citizens. The government has been involved in hundreds of foreign conflicts, and its president is considered a threat to the world due to their possession of large stockpiles of weapons. Furthermore, the author claims that the belief in a protective state is a patent error and that the American experiment in protective statism is a complete failure. The U.S. government is accused of expropriating more than 40 percent of the incomes of private producers, increasing financial insecurity through currency depreciation and eroding private property rights. The author also compares statists to socialists and states that as long as the essence of statism remains in place, no reform will make a difference.

The author argues that cost-accounting and monetary calculation are necessary for rational and efficient action in exchange economy based on division of labor. Cost-accounting is not possible under socialism as it lacks private ownership of factors of production, leading to economic chaos and regression to primitivism. The author cites Rothbard who explains that the state cannot be reformed but must be abolished to achieve justice and protection. Instead, a free market system of protection and defense would work effectively, with private property owners having the choice to cooperate with others or seek self-reliant defense. The author also credits Gustave de Molinari and Morris and Linda Tannehill's insights and analysis in this regard.

The text argues that protection and defense can be provided by insurance agencies. It is suggested that defense is a form of insurance, and therefore, the most likely organizations to offer protection services are insurance agencies. Insurance companies fulfill two essential requirements for providing protection services. Firstly, they must possess the economic means- manpower and physical resources- necessary to deal with the dangers of real life. Secondly, they must appear able to deliver on their promises to clients. The text explains that insurance agencies fit the bill as they operate on a nationwide and even international scale, own large property holdings dispersed over wide territories, and have a manifest self-interest in effective protection. The author clarifies that protection and defense are conditional insurance and not unconditional insurance. Only attacks and invasions that are provoked by the victim cannot be insured. The author explains that the system of competing insurers would significantly reduce conflict as it would allow for increased variability and flexibility of law. The system would also contribute to reducing conflict as insurance agencies could compete against each other through product differentiation, behavioral code imposed on clients, rules of evidence and procedure, and assignment of awards and punishments.

The author proposes a system of competing law codes offered by insurance agencies as a solution to reduce conflict. Under this system, consumers would have the choice to live under the law they prefer, and insurers would differentiate themselves through the behavioral code imposed on their clients and the rules of evidence, procedure, and awards and punishments. Even though domestic law codes would apply only to those insured by the same insurer, competition would promote the development and refinement of intergroup law that represents the greatest common denominator among different law codes. The relationship between insurers and arbitrators would be defined by contract and every change in the terms or conditions of a contract would require the unanimous consent of all parties concerned. In this system, every conflict and damage claim would fall into the jurisdiction of one or more specific insurance agencies, and everyone who buys protection insurance would become tied into a competitive enterprise aimed at reducing conflict and enhancing security.

The author addresses the issue of protection insurance and distinguishes it from natural disaster insurance. He argues that while both forms of insurance require the risk to be accidental, defense-protection insurance is distinct from natural disaster insurance in that it is the outcome of human actions, while natural disasters are the outcome of natural forces. Furthermore, while the borders of natural disaster regions are established according to objective physical criteria, political boundaries are artificial and can change over time. The author also notes that with advances in science and technology, risks that were previously considered homogeneous may become more specific and heterogeneous.

The author argues that the distinction between natural disasters and attacks made by an aggressor-invader is crucial. Natural disasters indiscriminately target locations and objects, while an aggressor-invader specifically targets valuable places and things. The author suggests that the borders of private property are the only nonarbitrary borders standing in systematic relation to the risk of aggression, meaning that as many different security zones as there are separately owned property holdings exist. The author notes that the risk of aggression against private property is different from one location to another and each location faces a unique security risk. The author argues that every owner will have to be insured individually and that every aggression insurer must hold sufficient capital reserves. The author also argues that the analogy drawn between insurance against natural disasters and external aggression is fundamentally flawed, as aggression is never indiscriminate but selective and targeted, so is defense. The existence of states changes the character of aggression and defense, implying that it tends to be transformed into total, indiscriminate war.

The author explains in this text how insurance companies and a completely stateless world would function. In such a world, the insurance companies would be endowed with significant capital reserves and would be the ones responsible for providing defense services to property owners. The attackers would only target uninsured property to avoid being confronted by powerful professional defense agencies. This would result in very selective and targeted defensive violence. On the other hand, in a statist world where there is interstate warfare, every individual from the attacking and attacked states is implicated in their respective government's actions. This means that war becomes total war and results in indiscriminate destruction and devastation. The author also discusses how a system of competitive insurance agencies would respond to the existence of states and state aggression. The answer lies in some basic economic insights such as people and goods tend to migrate from high-risk areas with falling property values to low-risk areas with increasing property values.

In a system of private, profit-driven insurance agencies, property owners would prefer to live and do business in low-risk areas with rising property values, rather than high-risk areas with falling property values. The cost of protection and property values are directly related, so insurance companies have an interest in promoting conditions favorable to rising property values. This changes the current crime policy, where government agents have little interest in being effective in preventing or compensating for crimes, and instead, taxes more in low crime areas and subsidizes high crime areas. In a system of competitive insurers, they would have an interest in preventing crimes, indemnifying victims, and efficiently detecting and punishing criminals. For this, insurers would maintain and continually update a detailed inventory of crimes and criminals, and share information with each other. They would also be interested in gathering information on potential crimes and aggressors, leading to a fundamental overhaul of current crime statistics. The risk of aggression would be assessed based on a multitude of crime indicators, such as the demographic characteristics of the neighborhood's inhabitants.

The author argues that a system of private protection insurers would be more efficient than the current state-run system. The official statistics on crime are often deliberately distorted to serve political purposes. The private protection insurers would eliminate the need for interlocal, regional, racial, national, ethnic, religious, and linguistic income and wealth redistribution. The insurers would promote a tendency toward civilizational progress by continuously updating and refining their system of statistics on crime and property values. The government's tax and transfer policy and its policy of forced integration would be eliminated under a system of private protection insurers, leading to a reduction in social conflict. The owners and residents of "good" locations would benefit from selective immigration, while those of "bad" locations would benefit from the ability to expel known criminals. Insurance companies would not be able to completely eliminate the differences between "good" and "bad" neighborhoods, but they would promote a tendency to improve both. The interests of the insurers and insured would coincide in both "good" and "bad" neighborhoods. The insurers would protect against state aggression by excluding all known government agents and treating them as undesirable outcasts.

If a government were to attack or invade a free territory, it would be difficult because there would be no state opponent, only private property owners and their insurance agencies. The power of any government rests on opinion and consent, so the leaders of the state would have to justify an attack and if they cannot, it would be considered extremely risky due to the risk of losing legitimacy and all of their power. A state attacking a free territory would encounter an armed population, as the insurers in free territories would encourage the ownership of weapons among their insured for self-defense. The aggressor would also run into resistance from multiple insurance and reinsurance agencies, who would be equipped and trained for the contingency of a state attack and ready to respond with a defense strategy. The insurers would be ready to expel, capture, or kill every invader while avoiding collateral damage, and target the aggressor (the state) for retaliation while seeking to avoid collateral damage to the property of innocent civilians. The authors believe that private insurance companies can minimize aggression and promote peace.

The author argues that the idea of a state as a protective entity is based on a flawed theory, which has caused destruction and insecurity to private property and perpetuated war. The solution to protect private property from aggression is through cooperation among private property owners, division of labor, and market competition. A system of private insurance agencies would minimize aggression and promote peace. To achieve this, people must withdraw their consent and cooperation from the state and delegitimize it in public opinion. If this were to happen, even the strongest government would collapse, and people would regain the right to self-defense and turn to insurance agencies for protection and conflict resolution.

header: 13: On the Impossibility of Limited Government and the Prospect for Revolution
content:
The author of this chapter argues that the sources of American national pride can be divided into three main categories. The first is the memory of America as a country of pioneers, where the English settlers coming to North America demonstrated the viability and the vibrancy of a stateless, anarcho-capitalist social order. The second source of pride is the American Revolution, which was a response to the growth of population, leading to the transformation of originally stateless societies into absolute monarchies in Europe with the power to tax without consent. The third source of pride, which the author considers a fateful error, is the claim that the U.S. is a "limited government."
