The author argues that, in reality, the U.S. government is not limited, but rather it has unlimited power over its citizens, including the power to tax and make decisions about the property of free men. The author suggests that this error might be repaired by a revolution, which would likely require a significant change in the current political and economic system and a return to a more anarcho-capitalist social order, similar to what was demonstrated by the English settlers in America's colonial past.

The author argues that the American colonies were ruled by an absolute king until 1688, which was extended to America when the English settlers arrived. The establishment of the royal colonies and administration was not a result of original appropriation and contract, but of usurpation and imposition. The settlers brought the doctrine of natural rights with them from Europe, where the development from feudalism to royal absolutism was opposed theoretically. The American colonists rose up against British rule since government was supposed to be contractual, and every government agent including the king was subject to the same universal rights and laws as everyone else. They drew their legitimacy from the consent of the governed. The author argues that the American Constitution represents a fateful error since once there is no longer free entry into the business of the production of protection and adjudication, the price of protection and justice will rise and their quality will fall. The compulsory monopolist will become a protection racketeer, destroying and invading the people and property it is supposed to protect.

Gustave de Molinari, a French-Belgian economist, stated in 1849 that it is in the consumer's best interest for labor and trade to be free, as it will result in the maximum reduction of prices. He believed that no government should prevent competition for security services or restrict consumers from purchasing security services elsewhere. On the other hand, if consumers are restricted, it leads to injustice, slow and costly administration of justice, vexatious police, and inflated pricing of security services. The Americans adopted a new constitution that replaced the king with a popularly elected parliament and president, but they retained the power to tax and legislate. The king's power to tax had only been assumed and was disputed, but the Constitution explicitly granted this power to Congress. The Constitution also vested the power of legislating with Congress and the powers of executing and interpreting legislated laws with the president and the Supreme Court, respectively. The new states of America did not let the colonial governments wither away and instead reconstituted them within their existing borders as independent states. The American Constitution established temporary caretakers who could exploit the country and its residents to their advantage during their tenure. This setup was predicted to lead to increased exploitation and less calculated and wasteful exploitation as self-interest drives the monopolist. Similar views about the permanency of law and the impermissibility of legislation were held by the 18th century French physiocrats such as Merrier de la Riviere.

The author argues that the idea of constitutional government as a civilizational advance over arbitrary government is flawed. The author suggests that pre-modern governments were more limited in their power to tax and legislate, while "constitutional" governments are defined by the recognition of these powers as legitimate. The author claims that open entry into government through political competition leads to the rise of "bad characters" and the distortion of society's character structure. The author also argues that the power of the state is limited by the prestige and functional importance of allegiances such as the church, family, gild, and local community. The author believes that private ownership is superior to government ownership, as private individuals have security in their property and can take a long term perspective. Political revolutions, according to the author, do not often accomplish anything of genuine value and simply replace one gang of thieves with another. In anarcho-capitalist society, coveting another's property is considered criminal and is suppressed, whereas under monarchical rule, only the king can act upon such desires, making him a potential threat.

According to the text, the selection of a king is based on pure accident of his noble birth and his upbringing as a future king. However, this fact does not guarantee that he will not be evil or that he will be a decent person. In an anarcho-capitalist society, people acting on their desire for another person's property are considered criminals and are suppressed by physical violence. Under monarchical rule, only the king can act on his desire for another man's property, making him a potential threat. On the other hand, the Constitution opens up entry into government and permits anyone to openly express their desire for other people's property, which in turn makes everyone a potential threat. If politics is allowed, even those who have no desire to enrich themselves at the expense of others will be affected. These honest, hardworking individuals will have to become political animals in order to defend their property and liberty from those who have fewer moral scruples. Given that the characteristics required for political success are unequal among men, those with these skills will have an advantage over those without them. The open political competition favors dangerous rather than harmless political talents and leads to the cultivation of demagoguery, deception, lying, corruption and bribery. The Constitution virtually assures that dangerous individuals will rise to the pinnacle of government power, resulting in the decline of moral behavior and ethical standards. The separation of powers provided by the Constitution fails to prevent the proliferation of error and all three branches of government work to expand their own power.

Rothbard critiques the notion of "constitutionally limited government" as a failure, pointing out that after more than two centuries of its existence, the situation has become considerably worse. The tax burden on Americans has increased dramatically, and the definition of private property has become more flexible and fluid. The right to self-defense has become less sacred, and the commitment to free trade and noninterventionism has given way to a policy of protectionism, militarism, and imperialism. In addition, while American citizens have become increasingly more defenseless, insecure, and impoverished, and foreigners all over the globe have become ever more threatened and bullied by U.S. military power, American presidents, members of Congress, and Supreme Court judges have become ever more arrogant, morally corrupt, and dangerous. The author argues that the idea of binding down power with the chains of a written constitution has proved to be a noble experiment that has failed and that some other, more radical means must be found to prevent the growth of the aggressive state.

The author argues that the American Constitution must be recognized as an error and an unconstitutional document, incompatible with the very doctrine of natural human rights that inspired the American Revolution. The author suggests that the provision of law and order by freely competing private insurance agencies is a positive and inspiring alternative to the present system. The author cites the example of insurance agencies, which protect private property owners against a multitude of natural and social disasters, and argues that the production of security and protection is the very purpose of insurance. People will check if the producer of security is really strong enough to protect them and whether his character is such that they will not have to worry about his instigating the very aggressions he is supposed to suppress.

Insurance agencies are seen as a possible alternative to the role performed by states as providers of law and order. Insurance agencies operate on a national or international scale, have a reputation for being effective, reliable and honest, and are connected through a complex network of contractual agreements. The relationship between insurers and insured is consensual, both are free to cooperate or not to cooperate, and this fact has momentous implications. Insurance agencies are categorically different from states as they cannot tax nor legislate. Competition among insurers for paying clients will bring about a tendency toward a continuous fall in the price of protection, which is more affordable than the monopolistic protector who may tax the protected. Insurers must indemnify their clients in case of actual damage, thus they must operate efficiently with the primary concern being effective prevention of crime. The voluntary relationship between insurers and clients means they must accept private property as an ultimate "given" and private property rights as immutable law.

Insurance agencies provide protection services to their clients through mutual interagency arbitration proceedings. This creates a universal law that minimizes conflict and aggression. In contrast, states, as tax-funded monopoly protectors, operate in a contractual void, allowing them to change rules as they go along. Insurance agencies are subject to independent third party arbitrators, while states assign arbitration to state-funded and dependent judges. Insurance agencies must accept private property as a given, while states typically outlaw the ownership of weapons by their clients. Insurance agencies are considered representative government because they enter into bilateral contracts with each client, while modern democratic government is a perversion of the original idea of representative government. Lysander Spooner argues that voting is not proof of consent and that elected officials are not our servants, agents, attorneys, or representatives.

The author explains that insurance involves the pooling of particular risks into risk classes and it is only possible to insure against an "accident" or a risk over which one has no control. The uninsurability of individual actions and sentiments implies that it is impossible to insure oneself against the risk of damages which are the result of one's prior aggression or provocation. Competition between insurers would encourage individual responsibility and exclude known provocateurs and aggressors. In addition, insurance companies would systematically promote the natural human tendency for "like people" to associate with each other and discriminate against "unlikes". The author states that in contrast to states, insurers will be prevented from engaging in any form of external aggression as any aggression is costly and requires higher insurance premiums.

The author argues that insurance agencies can provide a better protection service than the state. The state is prone to becoming an aggressor because it can externalize its costs onto hapless taxpayers. Insurance agencies, in contrast, are prevented from engaging in any form of aggression because it increases insurance premiums and reduces clients. The author argues that the power of every government rests solely on public opinion and not on physical force. The author argues for the right to self-determination and the need to respect the wishes of those who wish to secede from the state to which they belong.

The author believes that by creating a large number of territorially disconnected free cities in the United States, it would make it difficult for the central state to create opposition to the secessionists. If this strategy is successful, the author believes that it would be possible to return all public property into private hands, adopt a new constitution that declares all taxation and legislation unlawful, and allow insurance agencies to function as intended. The author cautions that the greatest danger of a government crackdown would be during the initial stage of this secessionist scenario, so it would be advisable to avoid direct confrontation with the central government.
